channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Volvo, Betting on Electric, Moves to Phase Out Conventional Engines
item.media:description: A Volvo plug-in hybrid at an auto show in Beijing in 2014.
item.description: It became the first mainstream automaker to sound the death knell of the traditional engine, saying all the models it introduces from 2019 will be either hybrids or powered solely by batteries.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: How Uber May Have Improperly Taxed Its Drivers
item.media:description: An Uber driver moving through the streets of Manhattan.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Drivers’ trip receipts contain signs that the ride-hailing service deducted hundreds of millions of dollars from drivers’ earnings in New York to pay state taxes.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER

item.title: A Backlash Builds Against Sexual Harassment in Silicon Valley
item.media:description: Dave McClure, the founder of 500 Startups, resigned on Monday.
item.description: A wave of revelations about investors mistreating female entrepreneurs has spurred the resignation of a prominent venture capitalist and calls for change.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER

item.title: Education Disrupted: How Silicon Valley Pushed Coding Into American Classrooms
item.media:description: Hadi Partovi, co-founder of Code.org.
item.media:credit: Koren Shadmi for The New York Times
item.description: Code.org, a tech-backed nonprofit, is pressing schools to teach computer science. But are tech firms swaying education to serve their own interests?
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER

item.title: Try, Then Buy? Amazon’s Move Is Part of a Shopping Trend
item.description: Fine jewelry, swimsuits and cocktail dresses are among the many items you can live with free for a while till it’s time to pay up or wrap up.
item.dc:creator: CLAIRE COGHLAN

item.title: Tech We're Using: In Reporting on North Korea, Tech Helps Break Through Secrecy
item.media:description: Choe Sang-Hun, The New York Times’s Korea correspondent, at a news conference in Seoul last week. In his backpack was a MacBook Air, while he held an iPhone and a notepad.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: But Choe Sang-Hun, The New York Times’s Korea correspondent, wishes that his iPhone could record phone conversations.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: Silicon Valley’s Financiers and Sexual Harassment
item.media:description: Rachel Renock, the chief executive of Wethos, center, with her business partners, Claire Humphreys, left, and Kristen Ablamsky. Ms. Renock said they received sexist comments while seeking financing.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.description: An environment in which entrepreneurs go hat-in-hand for financing from venture capitalists can be easily exploited.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Expanding Your View Beyond the Laptop Screen
item.media:description: When connected to a laptop, an external monitor can mirror the image of a smaller screen or serve as a secondary display that expands the desktop area.
item.description: Even if you have a laptop with the newer USB-C connections, you can find cables and adapters to hook up your small screen with a big monitor.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Konica Minolta, With Eye on Health Care, Nears Deal for U.S. Genetics Firm
item.media:description: Charles L. M. Dunlop, the founder and chairman of Ambry Genetics, has said his own experience with prostate cancer factored into his decision to make public anonymized information from the company’s database.
item.description: The Japanese company, which is trying to diversify its business, is said to be preparing to announce a $900 million deal to acquire the American testing company Ambry Genetics.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Emirates and Turkish Airlines Say Laptop Ban Is Lifted on Their U.S. Flights
item.media:description: An Emirates plane at Dubai International Airport in March.
item.description: The carriers joined Etihad Airlines, which was cleared over the weekend, in receiving an exemption to the restrictions on electronic devices.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tech Tip: Finding All Your Friends on the Map
item.description: Several apps can help you and your friends share your location information with each other, no matter which mobile platforms you use.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Worldpay Group, a British Payments Processor, Fields Two Possible Takeover Bids
item.description: The company said that it had been contacted by Vantiv, a rival payments company based in Cincinnati, and by the banking powerhouse JPMorgan Chase.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Uber Is Dealt a Fresh Blow in European Legal Case
item.media:description: Taxi drivers in Paris last month clashing with the police during a demonstration against Uber’s low-cost service, UberPop.
item.description: An advocate general’s recommendation to Europe’s highest court said that France could prohibit certain types of transport services it deemed illegal.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: On London’s Streets, Black Cabs and Uber Fight for a Future
item.media:description: A view of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament from a black cab in London.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: London’s cabby wars are less about the disruptive power of an app, or a new business model, than about the disruption of Britain.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Itineraries: Did You Pack Too Much? Your Suitcase Knows
item.media:description: Tim Ryan of Modobag riding one of the company’s motorized suitcases at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago. The suitcase is expected to be available this year.
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.description: The last big innovation in luggage was the introduction of wheels. Now, start-ups are building all types of new technology into their bags, like USB ports, GPS trackers and scales.
item.dc:creator: JULIE WEED

item.title: Harassment in the Tech Industry: Voices Grow on Social Media
item.media:description: Some readers were surprised that women in the technology industry came forward with stories of sexual harassment, given the risk of retaliation.
item.description: As readers respond to women’s accounts of sexual harassment in the technology industry, the investor Dave McClure announces his resignation from a firm he helped found.
item.dc:creator: KELLY COUTURIER

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: The Testing Labs of Malware
item.description: If you’ve developed new malicious software to break into a bank, do you test it out on Wall Street or in a developing economy?
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER
item.category: SWIFT(Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)

item.title: Tech Tip: After Ransomware Attack, Windows XP Is Not Back From the Dead
item.description: Microsoft recently issued an emergency patch for the operating system it retired in 2014, but the company has no plans to restore full support.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: When Just Vanilla Won’t Do, How About a Blueberry Pie Oreo?
item.description: The company has increasingly been experimenting with limited-edition flavors that seemed designed as much for an Instagram feed as they are to be eaten.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: At Their Leisure: Why Some Men Don’t Work: Video Games Have Gotten Really Good
item.media:description: As video games have gotten more technically advanced, they’ve also gotten more entrancing. Young men, in particular, are spending more time playing.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Young men are working less. Some economists think it’s because they’re home playing video games.
item.dc:creator: QUOCTRUNG BUI

item.title: Tesla’s First Mass-Market Car, the Model 3, Hits Production This Week
item.media:description: Tesla’s Model 3, which will sell for around $35,000. It is a critical test of the company’s plan to become a producer of mass-market electric cars.
item.description: As the electric-car maker moves to expand its lineup, it said problems with battery manufacturing had held down sales of existing models this year.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Hackers Find ‘Ideal Testing Ground’ for Attacks: Developing Countries
item.description: Often the best way to see if a cyberweapon works is to try it out in a country without the best digital defenses, as recent attacks have indicated.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: The South Park Commons Fills a Hole in the Tech Landscape
item.media:description: South Park Commons in San Francisco is the tech world’s answer to a French salon.
item.media:credit: Jason LeCras for The New York Times
item.description: The Bay Area tech scene has start-up incubators and hacker spaces. But what do you do when you want to figure out your next move?
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ

item.title: Bits: Mike’s and Kevin’s Week in Tech: Streaming Music and Harassment in Venture Capital
item.description: Two Times reporters discuss the Jay-Z album debut on Tidal, and the bad behavior that runs rampant in the venture capital industry.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and KEVIN ROOSE

item.title: Yelp’s Six-Year Grudge Against Google
item.description: Once courted, then spurned, the smaller rival sought revenge for years. Now Europe’s regulators give it reason to cheer.
item.dc:creator: CONOR DOUGHERTY

item.title: Women in Tech Speak Frankly on Culture of Harassment
item.media:description: Rachel Renock, the chief executive of Wethos, center, with her business partners, Claire Humphreys, left, and Kristen Ablamsky. Ms. Renock said they received sexist comments while seeking financing.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.description: More than two dozen women in the tech start-up industry spoke to The New York Times about being sexually harassed by investors and mentors.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: In Paris, They Do Start-Ups With Style
item.media:description: An office in Station F that will be home to Daphni, a venture capital firm.
item.media:credit: Roberto Frankenberg for The New York Times
item.description: The Silicon Valley workaholic ethos would never be confused with the French way of living. That’s not dissuading a group of tech entrepreneurs.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Deciding When to Use Your Own Router
item.media:description: Using the wireless router provided by your internet service provider can make for an easier tech-support experience, but you may not get as many features as you would with hardware you buy yourself.
item.description: A modem-router combination from your internet service provider usually means less setup and simpler technical support but, sometimes, fewer features.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Delete Hate Speech or Pay Up, Germany Tells Social Media Companies
item.media:description: A new law in Germany will require companies including Facebook, Twitter and Google, which owns YouTube, to remove any content that is illegal in Germany — such as Nazi symbols or Holocaust denial — within 24 hours of it being brought to their attention.
item.description: A new law will impose fines on companies like Facebook and Twitter if they fail to swiftly remove illegal or hateful content on their platforms.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Wheels: Why Fog Lamps Are Starting to Disappear
item.media:description: General Motors’ headquarters and other buildings in the Detroit skyline, obscured by early morning fog. Some automakers have quietly omitted front fog lights from many new models, saying that high-tech headlights make them unnecessary.
item.media:credit: Kevin Miyazaki for The New York Times
item.description: Several luxury automakers have moved away from fog lights, saying that new high-tech headlights render them obsolete.
item.dc:creator: JAMES G. COBB

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: When Ransomware Isn’t After a Ransom
item.media:description: On Wednesday, the calls for the National Security Agency to address its role in the latest hacking attacks grew louder from victims and tech companies.
item.description: The cyberattack that started in Ukraine and went global didn’t seem like an effort focused on making money.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Squeezing More Battery Juice Out of a Smartphone
item.description: If your phone is getting less time between trips to the charger, make sure external heat and power-hungry apps aren’t part of the problem.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Ask The Wirecutter: For the Best Internet at Home, Try These Tips on Wi-Fi Gear
item.media:description: Eero, one mesh networking kit. A mesh system will pick up and rebroadcast a Wi-Fi signal, extending the range.
item.description: Mesh networks appeal to people who aren’t happy with the speed of their current Wi-Fi system. But they’re not for everyone.
item.dc:creator: DAMON DARLIN

item.title: Trump, Amazon and ‘Internet Taxes’: What Did He Mean?
item.media:description: An employee of Amazon PrimeNow preparing bags to fill with orders at a distribution hub in New York.
item.description: A tweet may have implied support for legislation helping states force online retailers to collect sales taxes. But that is already Amazon’s practice.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN

item.title: Hacks Raise Fear Over N.S.A.’s Hold on Cyberweapons
item.media:description: On Wednesday, the calls for the National Security Agency to address its role in the latest hacking attacks grew louder from victims and tech companies.
item.description: Hackers in two global attacks have used cyberweapons stolen from a dangerous collection that had been amassed by the agency.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Samsung Joins Ranks of Foreign Firms Adding Jobs in the U.S.
item.media:description: Samsung plans to invest $380 million and hire over 950 workers for a new manufacturing plant for home appliances in South Carolina.
item.description: The South Korean company said it had considered opening an appliance plant for about three years, but the factory may help it stay on President Trump’s good side.
item.dc:creator: MICAH MAIDENBERG
